Tactics.Name: Change Lifestyle Habits
Tactics.Definition: Change Lifestyle Habits involves weight loss, reduced sodium intake, physical activity, limiting alcohol consumption, and diet.

Tactics.Name: Administer Beta-blocker (BB)
Tactics.Definition: Beta-blockers reduce heart rate and the force of contraction by blocking the effects of adrenaline (epinephrine) on beta-adrenergic receptors. This tactic includes three possible actions: stopping the drug, maintaining the current dosage, or increasing the dosage. It has a metric to track the maximum number of doses a patient can be prescribed.

Tactics.Name: Administer angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitor (ACE)
Tactics.Definition: ACE inhibitors block the enzyme that converts angiotensin I to angiotensin II, a hormone that narrows blood vessels. This causes vasodilation and reduces blood pressure. This tactic includes three possible actions: stopping the drug, maintaining the current dosage, or increasing the dosage. It has a metric to track the maximum number of doses a patient can be prescribed.

Tactics.Name: Administer Thiazide Diuretic (TD)
Tactics.Definition: Thiazides help the kidneys eliminate sodium and water, reducing blood volume and lowering blood pressure. This tactic includes three possible actions: stopping the drug, maintaining the current dosage, or increasing the dosage.  It has a metric to track the maximum number of doses a patient can be prescribed.

Metrics.Definition: Number of dosage of Thiazide Diuretic

Tactics.Name: Administer Angiotensin Receptor Blockers (ARB)
Tactics.Definition: ARBs block angiotensin II receptors, preventing blood vessel constriction, similar to ACE inhibitors, but without the cough side effect. This tactic includes three possible actions: stopping the drug, maintaining the current dosage, or increasing the dosage.  It has a metric to track the maximum number of doses a patient can be prescribed.

Tactics.Name: Administer Calcium Channel Blockers (CCB)
Tactics.Definition: CCBs prevent calcium from entering heart and blood vessel muscle cells. This relaxes vessels and reduces heart workload. This tactic includes three possible actions: stopping the drug, maintaining the current dosage, or increasing the dosage.  It has a metric to track the maximum number of doses a patient can be prescribed.
